Even then, it seemed to take forever for a spark to catch. He hung his cloak from the rock to keep the rain off his smoky little fire, making them a small snug alcove.</p>
      <p>As he knelt to skin the rabbit, Sam pulled off his boots. “I think there’s moss growing between my toes,” he declared mournfully, wriggling the toes in question. “The rabbit will taste good. I don’t even mind about the blood and all.” He looked away. “Well, only a little…”</p>
      <p>Jon spitted the carcass, banked the fire with a pair of rocks, and balanced their meal atop them. The rabbit had been a scrawny thing, but as it cooked it smelled like a king’s feast. Other rangers gave them envious looks. Even Ghost looked up hungrily, flames shining in his red eyes as he sniffed. “You had yours before,” Jon reminded him.</p>
      <p>“Is Craster as savage as the rangers say?” Sam asked. The rabbit was a shade underdone, but tasted wonderful. “What’s his castle like?”</p>
      <p>“A midden heap with a roof and a firepit.” Jon told Sam what he had seen and heard in Craster’s Keep.</p>
      <p>By the time the telling was done, it was dark outside and Sam was licking his fingers. “That was good, but now I’d like a leg of lamb. A whole leg, just for me, sauced with mint and honey and cloves. Did you see any lambs?”</p>
      <p>“There was a sheepfold, but no sheep.”</p>
      <p>“How does he feed all his men?”</p>
      <p>“I didn’t see any men. Just Craster and his women and a few small girls. I wonder he’s able to hold the place. His defenses were nothing to speak of, only a muddy dike. You had better go up to the hall and draw that map. Can you find the way?”</p>
      <p>“If I don’t fall in the mud.” Sam struggled back into his boots, collected quill and parchment, and shouldered out into the night, the rain pattering down on his cloak and floppy hat.</p>
      <p>Ghost laid his head on his paws and went to sleep by the fire. Jon stretched out beside him, grateful for the warmth. He was cold and wet, but not so cold and wet as he’d been a short time before. <emphasis>Perhaps tonight the Old Bear will learn something that will lead us to Uncle Benjen.</emphasis></p>
      <p>He woke to the sight of his own breath misting in the cold morning air. When he moved, his bones ached. Ghost was gone, the fire burnt out. Jon reached to pull aside the cloak he’d hung over the rock, and found it stiff and frozen. He crept beneath it and stood up in a forest turned to crystal.</p>
      <p>The pale pink light of dawn sparkled on branch and leaf and stone. Every blade of grass was carved from emerald, every drip of water turned to diamond. Flowers and mushrooms alike wore coats of glass. Even the mud puddles had a bright brown sheen. Through the shimmering greenery, the black tents of his brothers were encased in a fine glaze of ice.</p>
      <p><emphasis>So there is magic beyond the Wall after all.</emphasis> He found himself thinking of his sisters, perhaps because he’d dreamed of them last night. Sansa would call this an enchantment, and tears would fill her eyes at the wonder of it, but Arya would run out laughing and shouting, wanting to touch it all.</p>
      <p><emphasis>“Lord Snow?”</emphasis> he heard. Soft and meek. He turned.</p>
      <p>Crouched atop the rock that had sheltered him during the night was the rabbit keeper, wrapped in a black cloak so large it drowned her. <emphasis>Sam’s cloak,</emphasis> Jon realized at once. <emphasis>Why is she wearing Sam’s cloak?</emphasis> “The fat one told me I’d find you here, m’lord,” she said.</p>
      <p>“We ate the rabbit, if that’s what you came for.” The admission made him feel absurdly guilty.</p>
      <p>“Old Lord Crow, him with the talking bird, he gave Craster a crossbow worth a hundred rabbits.” Her arms closed over the swell of her belly. “Is it true, m’lord? Are you brother to a king?”</p>
      <p>“A half brother,” he admitted. “I’m Ned Stark’s bastard. My brother Robb is the King in the North. Why are you here?”</p>
      <p>“The fat one, that Sam, he said to see you. He give me his cloak, so no one would say I didn’t belong.”</p>
      <p>“Won’t Craster be angry with you?”</p>
      <p>“My father drank overmuch of the Lord Crow’s wine last night. He’ll sleep most of the day.” Her breath frosted the air in small nervous puffs. “They say the king gives justice and protects the weak.” She started to climb off the rock, awkwardly, but the ice had made it slippery and her foot went out from under her. Jon caught her before she could fall, and helped her safely down. The woman knelt on the icy ground. “M’lord, I beg you—”</p>
      <p>“Don’t beg me anything. Go back to your hall, you shouldn’t be here. We were commanded not to speak to Craster’s women.”</p>
      <p>“You don’t have to speak with me, m’lord. Just take me with you, when you go, that’s all I ask.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>All she asks,</emphasis> he thought. <emphasis>As if that were nothing.</emphasis></p>
      <p>“I’ll… I’ll be your wife, if you like. My father, he’s got nineteen now, one less won’t hurt him none.”</p>
      <p>“Black brothers are sworn never to take wives, don’t you know that? And we’re guests in your father’s hall besides.”</p>
      <p>“Not <emphasis>you,</emphasis>” she said. “I watched. You never ate at his board, nor slept by his fire. He never gave you guest-right, so you’re not bound to him. It’s for the baby I have to go.”</p>
      <p>“I don’t even know your name.”</p>
      <p>“Gilly, he called me. For the gillyflower.”</p>
      <p>“That’s pretty.” He remembered Sansa telling him once that he should say that whenever a lady told him her name. He could not help the girl, but perhaps the courtesy would please her. “Is it Craster who frightens you, Gilly?”</p>
      <p>“For the baby, not for me. If it’s a girl, that’s not so bad, she’ll grow a few years and he’ll marry her. But Nella says it’s to be a boy, and she’s had six and knows these things. He gives the boys to the gods. Come the white cold, he does, and of late it comes more often. That’s why he started giving them sheep, even though he has a taste for mutton. Only now the sheep’s gone too. Next it will be dogs, till…” She lowered her eyes and stroked her belly.</p>
      <p>“What gods?” Jon was remembering that they’d seen no boys in Craster’s Keep, nor men either, save Craster himself.</p>
      <p>“The cold gods,” she said. “The ones in the night. The white shadows.”</p>
      <p>And suddenly Jon was back in the Lord Commander’s Tower again. A severed hand was climbing his calf and when he pried it off with the point of his longsword, it lay writhing, fingers opening and closing. The dead man rose to his feet, blue eyes shining in that gashed and swollen face. Ropes of torn flesh hung from the great wound in his belly, yet there was no blood.</p>
      <p>“What color are their eyes?” he asked her.</p>
      <p>“Blue. As bright as blue stars, and as cold.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>She has seen them,</emphasis> he thought. <emphasis>Craster lied.</emphasis></p>
      <p>“Will you take me? Just so far as the Wall—”</p>
      <p>“We do not ride for the Wall. We ride north, after Mance Rayder and these Others, these white shadows and their wights. We <emphasis>seek</emphasis> them, Gilly. Your babe would not be safe with us.”</p>
      <p>Her fear was plain on her face. “You will come back, though. When your warring’s done, you’ll pass this way again.”</p>
      <p>“We may.” <emphasis>If any of us still live.</emphasis> “That’s for the Old Bear to say, the one you call the Lord Crow. I’m only his squire. I do not choose the road I ride.”</p>
      <p>“No.” He could hear the defeat in her voice. “Sorry to be of trouble, m’lord. I only… they said the king keeps people safe, and I thought…” Despairing, she ran, Sam’s cloak flapping behind her like great black wings.</p>
      <p>Jon watched her go, his joy in the morning’s brittle beauty gone. <emphasis>Damn her,</emphasis> he thought resentfully, <emphasis>and damn Sam twice for sending her to me. What did he think I could do for her? We’re here to fight wildlings, not save them.</emphasis></p>
      <p>Other men were crawling from their shelters, yawning and stretching. The magic was already faded, icy brightness turning back to common dew in the light of the rising sun. Someone had gotten a fire started; he could smell woodsmoke drifting through the trees, and the smoky scent of bacon. Jon took down his cloak and snapped it against the rock, shattering the thin crust of ice that had formed in the night, then gathered up Longclaw and shrugged an arm through a shoulder strap. A few yards away he made water into a frozen bush, his piss steaming in the cold air and melting the ice wherever it fell. Afterward he laced up his black wool breeches and followed the smells.</p>
      <p>Grenn and Dywen were among the brothers who had gathered round the fire. Hake handed Jon a hollow heel of bread filled with burnt bacon and chunks of salt fish warmed in bacon grease. He wolfed it down while listening to Dywen boast of having three of Craster’s women during the night.</p>
      <p>“You did not,” Grenn said, scowling. “I would have seen.”</p>
      <p>Dywen whapped him up alongside his ear with the back of his hand. “You? Seen? You’re blind as Maester Aemon. You never even saw that bear.”</p>
      <p>“What bear? Was there a bear?”</p>
      <p>“There’s always a bear,” declared Dolorous Edd in his usual tone of gloomy resignation. “One killed my brother when I was young. Afterward it wore his teeth around its neck on a leather thong. And they were good teeth too, better than mine. I’ve had nothing but trouble with my teeth.”</p>
      <p>“Did Sam sleep in the hall last night?” Jon asked him.</p>
      <p>“I’d not call it sleeping. The ground was hard, the rushes ill-smelling, and my brothers snore frightfully. Speak of bears if you will, none ever growled so fierce as Brown Bernarr. I was warm, though. Some dogs crawled atop me during the night. My cloak was almost dry when one of them pissed in it. Or perhaps it was Brown Bernarr. Have you noticed that the rain stopped the instant I had a roof above me? It will start again now that I’m back out. Gods and dogs alike delight to piss on me.”</p>
      <p>“I’d best go see to Lord Mormont,” said Jon.</p>
      <p>The rain might have stopped, but the compound was still a morass of shallow lakes and slippery mud. Black brothers were folding their tents, feeding their horses, and chewing on strips of salt beef. Jarman Buckwell’s scouts were tightening the girths on their saddles before setting out. “Jon,” Buckwell greeted him from horseback. “Keep a good edge on that bastard sword of yours. We’ll be needing it soon enough.”</p>
      <p>Craster’s hall was dim after daylight. Inside, the night’s torches had burned low, and it was hard to know that the sun had risen. Lord Mormont’s raven was the first to spy him enter. Three lazy flaps of its great black wings, and it perched atop Longclaw’s hilt. <emphasis>“Corn?”</emphasis> It nipped at a strand of Jon’s hair.</p>
      <p>“Ignore that wretched beggar bird, Jon, it’s just had half my bacon.” The Old Bear sat at Craster’s board, breaking his fast with the other officers on fried bread, bacon, and sheepgut sausage. Craster’s new axe was on the table, its gold inlay gleaming faintly in the torchlight. Its owner was sprawled unconscious in the sleeping loft above, but the women were all up, moving about and serving. “What sort of day do we have?”</p>
      <p>“Cold, but the rain has stopped.”</p>
      <p>“Very good. See that my horse is saddled and ready. I mean for us to ride within the hour. Have you eaten? Craster serves plain fare, but filling.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>I will not eat Craster’s food,</emphasis> he decided suddenly. “I broke my fast with the men, my lord.” Jon shooed the raven off Longclaw. The bird hopped back to Mormont’s shoulder, where it promptly shat. “You might have done that on Snow instead of saving it for me,” the Old Bear grumbled. The raven <emphasis>quorked</emphasis>.</p>
      <p>He found Sam behind the hall, standing with Gilly at the broken rabbit hutch. She was helping him back into his cloak, but when she saw Jon she stole away. Sam gave him a look of wounded reproach. “I thought you would help her.”</p>
      <p>“And how was I to do that?” Jon said sharply. “Take her with us, wrapped up in your cloak? We were commanded not to—”</p>
      <p>“I know,” said Sam guiltily, “but she was afraid. I know what it is to be afraid. I told her…” He swallowed.</p>
      <p>“<emphasis>What?</emphasis> That we’d take her with us?”</p>
      <p>Sam’s fat face blushed a deep red. “On the way home.” He could not meet Jon’s eyes. “She’s going to have a baby.”</p>
      <p>“Sam, have you taken leave of all your sense? We may not even return this way. And if we do, do you think the Old Bear is going to let you pack off one of Craster’s wives?”</p>
      <p>“I thought… maybe by then I could think of a way…”</p>
      <p>“I have no time for this, I have horses to groom and saddle.” Jon walked away as confused as he was angry. Sam’s heart was as big as the rest of him, but for all his reading he could be as thick as Grenn at times. It was impossible, and dishonorable besides. <emphasis>So why do I feel so ashamed?</emphasis></p>
      <p>Jon took his accustomed position at Mormont’s side as the Night’s Watch streamed out past the skulls on Craster’s gate. They struck off north and west along a crooked game trail. Melting ice dripped down all about them, a slower sort of rain with its own soft music. North of the compound, the brook was in full spate, choked with leaves and bits of wood, but the scouts had found where the ford lay and the column was able to splash across. The water ran as high as a horse’s belly. Ghost swam, emerging on the bank with his white fur dripping brown. When he shook, spraying mud and water in all directions, Mormont said nothing, but on his shoulder the raven screeched.</p>
      <p>“My lord,” Jon said quietly as the wood closed in around them once more. “Craster has no sheep. Nor any sons.”</p>
      <p>Mormont made no answer.</p>
      <p>“At Winterfell one of the serving women told us stories,” Jon went on. “She used to say that there were wildlings who would lay with the Others to birth half-human children.”</p>
      <p>“Hearth tales. Does Craster seem less than human to you?”</p>
      <p><emphasis>In half a hundred ways.</emphasis> “He gives his sons to the wood.”</p>
      <p>A long silence. Then: “Yes.” And <emphasis>“Yes,”</emphasis> the raven muttered, strutting. <emphasis>“Yes, yes, yes.”</emphasis></p>
      <p>“You knew?”</p>
      <p>“Smallwood told me. Long ago. All the rangers know, though few will talk of it.”</p>
      <p>“Did my uncle know?”</p>
      <p>“All the rangers,” Mormont repeated. “You think I ought to stop him. Kill him if need be.” The Old Bear sighed. “Were it only that he wished to rid himself of some mouths, I’d gladly send Yoren or Conwys to collect the boys. We could raise them to the black and the Watch would be that much the stronger. But the wildlings serve crueler gods than you or I. These boys are Craster’s offerings. His prayers, if you will.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>His wives must offer different prayers,</emphasis> Jon thought.</p>
      <p>“How is it you came to know this?” the Old Bear asked him. “From one of Craster’s wives?”</p>
      <p>“Yes, my lord,” Jon confessed. “I would sooner not tell you which. She was frightened and wanted help.”</p>
      <p>“The wide world is full of people wanting help, Jon. Would that some could find the courage to help themselves. Craster sprawls in his loft even now, stinking of wine and lost to sense. On his board below lies a sharp new axe. Were it me, I’d name it “Answered Prayer’ and make an end.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>Yes.</emphasis> Jon thought of Gilly. She and her sisters. They were nineteen, and Craster was one, but…</p>
      <p>“Yet it would be an ill day for us if Craster died. Your uncle could tell you of the times Craster’s Keep made the difference between life and death for our rangers.”</p>
      <p>“My father…” He hesitated.</p>
      <p>“Go on, Jon. Say what you would say.”</p>
      <p>“My father once told me that some men are not worth having,” Jon finished. “A bannerman who is brutal or unjust dishonors his liege lord as well as himself.”</p>
      <p>“Craster is his own man. He has sworn us no vows. Nor is he subject to our laws. Your heart is noble, Jon, but learn a lesson here. We cannot set the world to rights. That is not our purpose. The Night’s Watch has other wars to fight.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>Other wars. Yes. I must remember.</emphasis> “Jarman Buckwell said I might have need of my sword soon.”</p>
      <p>“Did he?” Mormont did not seem pleased. “Craster said much and more last night, and confirmed enough of my fears to condemn me to a sleepless night on his floor. Mance Rayder is gathering his people together in the Frostfangs. That’s why the villages are empty. It is the same tale that Ser Denys Mallister had from the wildling his men captured in the Gorge, but Craster has added the <emphasis>where,</emphasis> and that makes all the difference.”</p>
      <p>“Is he making a city, or an army?”</p>
      <p>“Now, that is the question. How many wildlings are there? How many men of fighting age? No one knows with certainty. The Frostfangs are cruel, inhospitable, a wilderness of stone and ice. They will not long sustain any great number of people. I can see only one purpose in this gathering. Mance Rayder means to strike south, into the Seven Kingdoms.”</p>
      <p>“Wildlings have invaded the realm before.” Jon had heard the tales from Old Nan and Maester Luwin both, back at Winterfell. “Raymun Redbeard led them south in the time of my grandfather’s grandfather, and before him there was a king named Bael the Bard.”</p>
      <p>“Aye, and long before them came the Horned Lord and the brother kings Gendel and Gorne, and in ancient days Joramun, who blew the Horn of Winter and woke giants from the earth. Each man of them broke his strength on the Wall, or was broken by the power of Winterfell on the far side… but the Night’s Watch is only a shadow of what we were, and who remains to oppose the wildlings besides us? The Lord of Winterfell is dead, and his heir has marched his strength south to fight the Lannisters. The wildlings may never again have such a chance as this. I knew Mance Rayder, Jon. He is an oathbreaker, yes… but he has eyes to see, and no man has ever dared to name him faintheart.”</p>
      <p>“What will we do?” asked Jon.</p>
      <p>“Find him,” said Mormont. “Fight him. Stop him.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>Three hundred,</emphasis> thought Jon, <emphasis>against the fury of the wild.</emphasis> His fingers opened and closed.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
      <title>
        <p>THEON</p>
      </title>
      <p>She was undeniably a beauty. <emphasis>But your first is always beautiful,</emphasis> Theon Greyjoy thought.</p>
      <p>“Now there’s a pretty grin,” a woman’s voice said behind him. “The lordling likes the look of her, does he?”</p>
      <p>Theon turned to give her an appraising glance. He liked what he saw. Ironborn, he knew at a glance; lean and long-legged, with black hair cut short, wind-chafed skin, strong sure hands, a dirk at her belt. Her nose was too big and too sharp for her thin face, but her smile made up for it. He judged her a few years older than he was, but no more than five-and-twenty. She moved as if she were used to a deck beneath her feet.</p>
      <p>“Yes, she’s a sweet sight,” he told her, “though not half so sweet as you.”</p>
      <p>“Oho.” She grinned. “I’d best be careful. This lordling has a honeyed tongue.”</p>
      <p>“Taste it and see.”</p>
      <p>“Is it that way, then?” she said, eyeing him boldly. There were women on the Iron Islands — not many, but a few — who crewed the longships along with their men, and it was said that salt and sea changed them, gave them a man’s appetites. “Have you been that long at sea, lordling? Or were there no women where you came from?”</p>
      <p>“Women enough, but none like you.”</p>
      <p>“And how would you know what I’m like?”</p>
      <p>“My eyes can see your face. My ears can hear your laughter. And my cock’s gone hard as a mast for you.”</p>
      <p>The woman stepped close and pressed a hand to the front of his breeches. “Well, you’re no liar,” she said, giving him a squeeze through the cloth. “How bad does it hurt?”</p>
      <p>“Fiercely.”</p>
      <p>“Poor lordling.” She released him and stepped back. “As it happens, I’m a woman wed, and new with child.”</p>
      <p>“The gods are good,” Theon said. “No chance I’d give you a bastard that way.”</p>
      <p>“Even so, my man wouldn’t thank you.”</p>
      <p>“No, but you might.”</p>
      <p>“And why would that be? I’ve had lords before. They’re made the same as other men.”</p>
      <p>“Have you ever had a prince?” he asked her. “When you’re wrinkled and grey and your teats hang past your belly, you can tell your children’s children that once you loved a king.”</p>
      <p>“Oh, is it love we’re talking now? And here I thought it was just cocks and cunts.”</p>
      <p>“Is it love you fancy?” He’d decided that he liked this wench, whoever she was; her sharp wit was a welcome respite from the damp gloom of Pyke. “Shall I name my longship after you, and play you the high harp, and keep you in a tower room in my castle with only jewels to wear, like a princess in a song?”</p>
      <p>“You <emphasis>ought</emphasis> to name your ship after me,” she said, ignoring all the rest. “It was me who built her.”</p>
      <p>“Sigrin built her. My lord father’s shipwright.”</p>
      <p>“I’m Esgred. Ambrode’s daughter, and wife to Sigrin.”</p>
      <p>He had not known that Ambrode had a daughter, or Sigrin a wife… but he’d met the younger shipwright only once, and the older one he scarce remembered. “You’re wasted on Sigrin.”</p>
      <p>“Oho. Sigrin told me this sweet ship is wasted on you.”</p>
      <p>Theon bristled. “Do you know who I am?”</p>
      <p>“Prince Theon of House Greyjoy. Who else? Tell me true, my lord, how well do you love her, this new maid of yours? Sigrin will want to know.”</p>
      <p>The longship was so new that she still smelled of pitch and resin. His uncle Aeron would bless her on the morrow, but Theon had ridden over from Pyke to get a look at her before she was launched. She was not so large as Lord Balon’s own <emphasis>Great Kraken</emphasis> or his uncle Victarion’s <emphasis>Iron Victory,</emphasis> but she looked swift and sweet, even sitting in her wooden cradle on the strand; lean black hull a hundred feet long, a single tall mast, fifty long oars, deck enough for a hundred men… and at the prow, the great iron ram in the shape of an arrowhead. “Sigrin did me good service,” he admitted. “Is she as fast as she looks?”</p>
      <p>“Faster — for a master that knows how to handle her.”</p>
      <p>“It has been a few years since I sailed a ship.” <emphasis>And I’ve never captained one, if truth be told.</emphasis> “Still, I’m a Greyjoy, and an ironman. The sea is in my blood.”</p>
      <p>“And your blood will be in the sea, if you sail the way you talk,” she told him.</p>
      <p>“I would never mistreat such a fair maiden.”</p>
      <p>“Fair maiden?” She laughed. “She’s a sea bitch, this one.”</p>
      <p>“There, and now you’ve named her. <emphasis>Sea Bitch.</emphasis>”</p>
      <p>That amused her; he could see the sparkle in her dark eyes. “And you said you’d name her after me,” she said in a voice of wounded reproach.</p>
      <p>“I did.” He caught her hand. “Help me, my lady. In the green lands, they believe a woman with child means good fortune for any man who beds her.”</p>
      <p>“And what would they know about ships in the green lands? Or women, for that matter? Besides, I think you made that up.”</p>
      <p>“If I confess, will you still love me?”</p>
      <p>“Still? When have I ever loved you?”</p>
      <p>“Never,” he admitted, “but I am trying to repair that lack, my sweet Esgred. The wind is cold. Come aboard my ship and let me warm you. On the morrow my uncle Aeron will pour seawater over her prow and mumble a prayer to the Drowned God, but I’d sooner bless her with the milk of my loins, and yours.”</p>
      <p>“The Drowned God might not take that kindly.”</p>
      <p>“Bugger the Drowned God. If he troubles us, I’ll drown him again. We’re off to war within a fortnight. Would you send me into battle all sleepless with longing?”</p>
      <p>“Gladly.”</p>
      <p>“A cruel maid. My ship is well named. If I steer her onto the rocks in my distraction, you’ll have yourself to blame.”</p>
      <p>“Do you plan to steer with this?” Esgred brushed the front of his breeches once more, and smiled as a finger traced the iron outline of his manhood.</p>
      <p>“Come back to Pyke with me,” he said suddenly, thinking, <emphasis>What will Lord Balon say? And why should I care? I am a man grown, if I want to bring a wench to bed it is no one’s business but my own.</emphasis></p>
      <p>“And what would I do in Pyke?” Her hand stayed where it was.</p>
      <p>“My father will feast his captains tonight.” He had them to feast every night, while he waited for the last stragglers to arrive, but Theon saw no need to tell all that.</p>
      <p>“Would you make me your captain for the night, my lord prince?” She had the wickedest smile he’d ever seen on a woman.</p>
      <p>“I might. If I knew you’d steer me safe into port.”</p>
      <p>“Well, I know which end of the oar goes in the sea, and there’s no one better with ropes and knots.” One-handed, she undid the lacing of his breeches, then grinned and stepped lightly away from him. “A pity I’m a woman wed, and new with child.”</p>
      <p>Flustered, Theon laced himself back up. “I need to start back to the castle. If you do not come with me, I may lose my way for grief, and all the islands would be poorer.”</p>
      <p>“We couldn’t have that… but I have no horse, my lord.”</p>
      <p>“You could take my squire’s mount.”</p>
      <p>“And leave your poor squire to walk all the way to Pyke?”</p>
      <p>“Share mine, then.”</p>
      <p>“You’d like that well enough.” The smile again. “Now, would I be behind you, or in front?”</p>
      <p>“You would be wherever you liked.”</p>
      <p>“I like to be on top.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>Where has this wench been all my life?</emphasis> “My father’s hall is dim and dank. It needs Esgred to make the fires blaze.”</p>
      <p>“The lordling has a honeyed tongue.”</p>
      <p>“Isn’t that where we began?”</p>
      <p>She threw up her hands. “And where we end. Esgred is yours, sweet prince. Take me to your castle. Let me see your proud towers rising from the sea.”</p>
      <p>“I left my horse at the inn. Come.” They walked down the strand together, and when Theon took her arm, she did not pull away. He liked the way she walked; there was a boldness to it, part saunter and part sway, that suggested she would be just as bold beneath the blankets.</p>
      <p>Lordsport was as crowded as he’d ever seen it, swarming with the crews of the longships that lined the pebbled shore and rode at anchor well out past the breakwater. Ironmen did not bend their knees often nor easily, but Theon noted that oarsmen and townfolk alike grew quiet as they passed, and acknowledged him with respectful bows of the head. <emphasis>They have finally learned who I am,</emphasis> he thought. <emphasis>And past time too.</emphasis></p>
      <p>Lord Goodbrother of Great Wyk had come in the night before with his main strength, near forty longships. His men were everywhere, conspicuous in their striped goat’s hair sashes. It was said about the inn that Otter Gimpknee’s whores were being fucked bowlegged by beardless boys in sashes. The boys were welcome to them so far as Theon was concerned. A poxier den of slatterns he hoped he’d never see. His present companion was more to his taste. That she was wed to his father’s shipwright and pregnant to boot only made her more intriguing.</p>
      <p>“Has my lord prince begun choosing his crew?” Esgred asked as they made their way toward the stable. “Ho, Bluetooth,” she shouted to a passing seafarer, a tall man in bearskin vest and raven-winged helm. “How fares your bride?”</p>
      <p>“Fat with child, and talking of twins.”</p>
      <p>“So soon?” Esgred smiled that wicked smile. “You got your oar in the water quickly.”</p>
      <p>“Aye, and stroked and stroked and <emphasis>stroked,</emphasis>” roared the man.</p>
      <p>“A big man,” Theon observed. “Bluetooth, was it? Should I choose him for my <emphasis>Sea Bitch</emphasis>?”</p>
      <p>“Only if you mean to insult him. Bluetooth has a sweet ship of his own.”</p>
      <p>“I have been too long away to know one man from another,” Theon admitted. He’d looked for a few of the friends he’d played with as a boy, but they were gone, dead, or grown into strangers. “My uncle Victarion has loaned me his own steersman.”</p>
      <p>“Rymolf Stormdrunk? A good man, so long as he’s sober.” She saw more faces she knew, and called out to a passing trio, “Uller, Qarl. Where’s your brother, Skyte?”</p>
      <p>“The Drowned God needed a strong oarsman, I fear,” replied the stocky man with the white streak in his beard.</p>
      <p>“What he means is, Eldiss drank too much wine and his fat belly burst,” said the pink-cheeked youth beside him.</p>
      <p>“What’s dead may never die,” Esgred said.</p>
      <p>“What’s dead may never die.”</p>
      <p>Theon muttered the words with them. “You seem well known,” he said to the woman when the men had passed on.</p>
      <p>“Every man loves the shipwright’s wife. He had better, lest he wants his ship to sink. If you need men to pull your oars, you could do worse than those three.”</p>
      <p>“Lordsport has no lack of strong arms.” Theon had given the matter no little thought. It was fighters he wanted, and men who would be loyal to <emphasis>him,</emphasis> not to his lord father or his uncles. He was playing the part of a dutiful young prince for the moment, while he waited for Lord Balon to reveal the fullness of his plans. If it turned out that he did not like those plans or his part in them, however, well…</p>
      <p>“Strength is not enough. A longship’s oars must move as one if you would have her best speed. Choose men who have rowed together before, if you’re wise.”</p>
      <p>“Sage counsel. Perhaps you’d help me choose them.” <emphasis>Let her believe I want her wisdom, women fancy that.</emphasis></p>
      <p>“I may. If you treat me kindly.”</p>
      <p>“How else?”</p>
      <p>Theon quickened his stride as they neared the <emphasis>Myraham,</emphasis> rocking high and empty by the quay. Her captain had tried to sail a fortnight past, but Lord Balon would not permit it. None of the merchantmen that called at Lordsport had been allowed to depart again; his father wanted no word of the hosting to reach the mainland before he was ready to strike.</p>
      <p>“Milord,” a plaintive voice called down from the forecastle of the merchanter. The captain’s daughter leaned over the rail, gazing after him. Her father had forbidden her to come ashore, but whenever Theon came to Lordsport he spied her wandering forlornly about the deck. “Milord, a moment,” she called after him. “As it please milord…”</p>
      <p>“Did she?” Esgred asked as Theon hurried her past the cog. “Please milord?”</p>
      <p>He saw no sense in being coy with this one. “For a time. Now she wants to be my salt wife.”</p>
      <p>“Oho. Well, she’d profit from some salting, no doubt. Too soft and bland, that one. Or am I wrong?”</p>
      <p>“You’re not wrong.” <emphasis>Soft and bland. Precisely. How had she known?</emphasis></p>
      <p>He had told Wex to wait at the inn. The common room was so crowded that Theon had to push his way through the door. Not a seat was to be had at bench nor table. Nor did he see his squire. <emphasis>“Wex,”</emphasis> he shouted over the din and clatter. <emphasis>If he’s up with one of those poxy whores, I’ll strip the hide off him,</emphasis> he was thinking when he finally spied the boy, dicing near the hearth… and winning too, by the look of the pile of coins before him.</p>
      <p>“Time to go,” Theon announced. When the boy paid him no mind, he seized him by the ear and pulled him from the game. Wex grabbed up a fistful of coppers and came along without a word. That was one of the things Theon liked best about him. Most squires have loose tongues, but Wex had been born dumb… which didn’t seem to keep him from being clever as any twelve-year-old had a right to be. He was a baseborn son of one of Lord Botley’s half brothers. Taking him as squire had been part of the price Theon had paid for his horse.</p>
      <p>When Wex saw Esgred, his eyes went round. <emphasis>You’d think he’d never seen a woman before,</emphasis> Theon thought. “Esgred will be riding with me back to Pyke. Saddle the horses, and be quick about it.”</p>
      <p>The boy had ridden in on a scrawny little garron from Lord Balon’s stable, but Theon’s mount was quite another sort of beast. “Where did you find that hellhorse?” Esgred asked when she saw him, but from the way she laughed he knew she was impressed.</p>
      <p>“Lord Botley bought him in Lannisport a year past, but he proved to be too much horse for him, so Botley was pleased to sell.” The Iron Islands were too sparse and rocky for breeding good horses. Most of the islanders were indifferent riders at best, more comfortable on the deck of a longship than in the saddle. Even the lords rode garrons or shaggy Harlaw ponies, and ox carts were more common than drays. The smallfolk too poor to own either one pulled their own plows through the thin, stony soil.</p>
      <p>But Theon had spent ten years in Winterfell, and did not intend to go to war without a good mount beneath him. Lord Botley’s misjudgment was his good fortune: a stallion with a temper as black as his hide, larger than a courser if not quite so big as most destriers. As Theon was not quite so big as most knights, that suited him admirably. The animal had fire in his eyes. When he’d met his new owner, he’d pulled back his lips and tried to bite off his face.</p>
      <p>“Does he have a name?” Esgred asked Theon as he mounted.</p>
      <p>“Smiler.” He gave her a hand, and pulled her up in front of him, where he could put his arms around her as they rode. “I knew a man once who told me that I smiled at the wrong things.”</p>
      <p>“Do you?”</p>
      <p>“Only by the lights of those who smile at nothing.” He thought of his father and his uncle Aeron.</p>
      <p>“Are you smiling now, my lord prince?”</p>
      <p>“Oh, yes.” Theon reached around her to take the reins. She was almost of a height with him. Her hair could have used a wash and she had a faded pink scar on her pretty neck, but he liked the smell of her, salt and sweat and woman.</p>
      <p>The ride back to Pyke promised to be a good deal more interesting than the ride down had been.</p>
      <p>When they were well beyond Lordsport, Theon put a hand on her breast. Esgred reached up and plucked it away. “I’d keep both hands on the reins, or this black beast of yours is like to fling us both off and kick us to death.”</p>
      <p>“I broke him of that.” Amused, Theon behaved himself for a while, chatting amiably of the weather (grey and overcast, as it had been since he arrived, with frequent rains) and telling her of the men he’d killed in the Whispering Wood. When he reached the part about coming <emphasis>that</emphasis> close to the Kingslayer himself, he slid his hand back up to where it had been. Her breasts were small, but he liked the firmness of them.</p>
      <p>“You don’t want to do that, my lord prince.”</p>
      <p>“Oh, but I do.” Theon gave her a squeeze.</p>
      <p>“Your squire is watching you.”</p>
      <p>“Let him. He’ll never speak of it, I swear.”</p>
      <p>Esgred pried his fingers off her breast. This time she kept him firmly prisoned. She had strong hands.</p>
      <p>“I like a woman with a good tight grip.”</p>
      <p>She snorted. “I’d not have thought it, by that wench on the waterfront.”</p>
      <p>“You must not judge me by her. She was the only woman on the ship.”</p>
      <p>“Tell me of your father. Will he welcome me kindly to his castle?”</p>
      <p>“Why should he? He scarcely welcomed <emphasis>me,</emphasis> his own blood, the heir to Pyke and the Iron Islands.”</p>
      <p>“Are you?” she asked mildly. “It’s said that you have uncles, brothers, a sister.”</p>
      <p>“My brothers are long dead, and my sister… well, they say Asha’s favorite gown is a chainmail hauberk that hangs down past her knees, with boiled leather smallclothes beneath. Men’s garb won’t make her a man, though. I’ll make a good marriage alliance with her once we’ve won the war, if I can find a man to take her. As I recall, she had a nose like a vulture’s beak, a ripe crop of pimples, and no more chest than a boy.”</p>
      <p>“You can marry off your sister,” Esgred observed, “but not your uncles.”</p>
      <p>“My uncles…” Theon’s claim took precedence over those of his father’s three brothers, but the woman had touched on a sore point nonetheless. In the islands it was scarce unheard of for a strong, ambitious uncle to dispossess a weak nephew of his rights, and usually murder him in the bargain. <emphasis>But I am not weak,</emphasis> Theon told himself, <emphasis>and I mean to be stronger yet by the time my father dies.</emphasis> “My uncles pose no threat to me,” he declared. “Aeron is drunk on seawater and sanctity. He lives only for his god—”</p>
      <p>“<emphasis>His</emphasis> god? Not yours?”</p>
      <p>“Mine as well. What is dead can never die.” He smiled thinly. “If I make pious noises as required, Damphair will give me no trouble. And my uncle Victarion—”</p>
      <p>“Lord Captain of the Iron Fleet, and a fearsome warrior. I have heard them sing of him in the alehouses.”</p>
      <p>“During my lord father’s rebellion, he sailed into Lannisport with my uncle Euron and burned the Lannister fleet where it lay at anchor,” Theon recalled. “The plan was Euron’s, though. Victarion is like some great grey bullock, strong and tireless and dutiful, but not like to win any races. No doubt, he’ll serve me as loyally as he has served my lord father. He has neither the wits nor the ambition to plot betrayal.”</p>
      <p>“Euron Croweye has no lack of cunning, though. I’ve heard men say terrible things of that one.”</p>
      <p>Theon shifted his seat. “My uncle Euron has not been seen in the islands for close on two years. He may be dead.” If so, it might be for the best. Lord Balon’s eldest brother had never given up the Old Way, even for a day. His <emphasis>Silence,</emphasis> with its black sails and dark red hull, was infamous in every port from Ibben to Asshai, it was said.</p>
      <p>“He may be dead,” Esgred agreed, “and if he lives, why, he has spent so long at sea, he’d be half a stranger here. The ironborn would never seat a stranger in the Seastone Chair.”</p>
      <p>“I suppose not,” Theon replied, before it occurred to him that some would call <emphasis>him</emphasis> a stranger as well. The thought made him frown. <emphasis>Ten years is a long while, but I am back now, and my father is far from dead. I have time to prove myself.</emphasis></p>
      <p>He considered fondling Esgred’s breast again, but she would probably only take his hand away, and all this talk of his uncles had dampened his ardor somewhat. Time enough for such play at the castle, in the privacy of his chambers. “I will speak to Helya when we reach Pyke, and see that you have an honored place at the feast,” he said. “I must sit on the dais, at my father’s right hand, but I will come down and join you when he leaves the hall. He seldom lingers long. He has no belly for drink these days.”</p>
      <p>“A grievous thing when a great man grows old.”</p>
      <p>“Lord Balon is but the <emphasis>father</emphasis> of a great man.”</p>
      <p>“A modest lordling.”</p>
      <p>“Only a fool humbles himself when the world is so full of men eager to do that job for him.” He kissed her lightly on the nape of her neck.</p>
      <p>“What shall I wear to this great feast?” She reached back and pushed his face away.</p>
      <p>“I’ll ask Helya to garb you. One of my lady mother’s gowns might do. She is off on Harlaw, and not expected to return.”</p>
      <p>“The cold winds have worn her away, I hear. Will you not go see her? Harlaw is only a day’s sail, and surely Lady Greyjoy yearns for a last sight of her son.”</p>
      <p>“Would that I could. I am kept too busy here. My father relies on me, now that I am returned. Come peace, perhaps…”</p>
      <p>“Your coming might bring <emphasis>her</emphasis> peace.”</p>
      <p>“Now you sound a woman,” Theon complained.</p>
      <p>“I confess, I am… and new with child.”</p>
      <p>Somehow that thought excited him. “So you say, but your body shows no signs of it. How shall it be proven? Before I believe you, I shall need to see your breasts grow ripe, and taste your mother’s milk.”</p>
      <p>“And what will my husband say to this? Your father’s own sworn man and servant?”</p>
      <p>“We’ll give him so many ships to build, he’ll never know you’ve left him.”</p>
      <p>She laughed. “It’s a cruel lordling who’s seized me. If I promise you that one day you may watch my babe get suck, will you tell me more of your war, Theon of House Greyjoy? There are miles and mountains still ahead of us, and I would hear of this wolf king you served, and the golden lions he fights.”</p>
      <p>Ever anxious to please her, Theon obliged. The rest of the long ride passed swiftly as he filled her pretty head with tales of Winterfell and war. Some of the things he said astonished him. <emphasis>She is easy to talk to, gods praise her,</emphasis> he reflected. <emphasis>I feel as though I’ve known her for years. If the wench’s pillow play is half the equal of her wit, I’ll need to keep her… </emphasis>He thought of Sigrin the Shipwright, a thick-bodied, thick-witted man, flaxen hair already receding from a pimpled brow, and shook his head. <emphasis>A waste. A most tragic waste.</emphasis></p>
      <p>It seemed scarcely any time at all before the great curtain wall of Pyke loomed up before them.</p>
      <p>The gates were open. Theon put his heels into Smiler and rode through at a brisk trot. The hounds were barking wildly as he helped Esgred dismount. Several came bounding up, tails wagging. They shot straight past him and almost bowled the woman over, leaping all around her, yapping and licking. <emphasis>“Off,”</emphasis> Theon shouted, aiming an ineffectual kick at one big brown bitch, but Esgred was laughing and wrestling with them.</p>
      <p>A stableman came pounding up after the dogs. “Take the horse,” Theon commanded him, “and get these damn dogs away—”</p>
      <p>The lout paid him no mind. His face broke into a huge gap-toothed smile and he said, “Lady Asha. You’re back.”</p>
      <p>“Last night,” she said. “I sailed from Great Wyk with Lord Goodbrother, and spent the night at the inn. My little brother was kind enough to let me ride with him from Lordsport.” She kissed one of the dogs on the nose and grinned at Theon.</p>
      <p>All he could do was stand and gape at her. <emphasis>Asha. No. She cannot be Asha.</emphasis> He realized suddenly that there were two Ashas in his head. One was the little girl he had known. The other, more vaguely imagined, looked something like her mother. Neither looked a bit like this… this… this…</p>
      <p>“The pimples went when the breasts came,” she explained while she tussled with a dog, “but I kept the vulture’s beak.”</p>
      <p>Theon found his voice. <emphasis>“Why didn’t you tell me?”</emphasis></p>
      <p>Asha let go of the hound and straightened. “I wanted to see who you were first. And I did.” She gave him a mocking half bow. “And now, little brother, pray excuse me. I need to bathe and dress for the feast. I wonder if I still have that chainmail gown I like to wear over my boiled leather smallclothes?” She gave him that evil grin, and crossed the bridge with that walk he’d liked so well, half saunter and half sway.</p>
      <p>When Theon turned away, Wex was smirking at him. He gave the boy a clout on the ear. “That’s for enjoying this so much.” And another, harder. “And that’s for not warning me. Next time, grow a tongue.”</p>
      <p>His own chambers in the Guest Keep had never seemed so chilly, though the thralls had left a brazier burning. Theon kicked his boots off, let his cloak fall to the floor, and poured himself a cup of wine, remembering a gawky girl with knob knees and pimples. <emphasis>She unlaced my breeches,</emphasis> he thought, outraged, <emphasis>and she said… oh, gods, and</emphasis> I <emphasis>said… </emphasis>He groaned. He could not possibly have made a more appalling fool of himself.</p>
      <p><emphasis>No,</emphasis> he thought then. <emphasis>She was the one who made me a fool. The evil bitch must have enjoyed every moment of it. And the way she kept reaching for my cock…</emphasis></p>
      <p>He took his cup and went to the window seat, where he sat drinking and watching the sea while the sun darkened over Pyke. <emphasis>I have no place here,</emphasis> he thought, <emphasis>and Asha is the reason, may the Others take her!</emphasis> The water below turned from green to grey to black. By then he could hear distant music, and he knew it was time to change for the feast.</p>
      <p>Theon chose plain boots and plainer clothes, somber shades of black and grey to fit his mood. No ornament; he had nothing bought with iron. <emphasis>I might have taken something off that wildling I killed to save Bran Stark, but he had nothing worth the taking. That’s my cursed luck, I kill the poor.</emphasis></p>
      <p>The long smoky hall was crowded with his father’s lords and captains when Theon entered, near four hundred of them. Dagmer Cleftjaw had not yet returned from Old Wyk with the Stonehouses and Drumms, but all the rest were there — Harlaws from Harlaw, Blacktydes from Blacktyde, Sparrs, Merlyns, and Goodbrothers from Great Wyk, Saltcliffes and Sunderlies from Saltcliffe, and Botleys and Wynches from the other side of Pyke. The thralls were pouring ale, and there was music, fiddles and skins and drums. Three burly men were doing the finger dance, spinning short-hafted axes at each other. The trick was to catch the axe or leap over it without missing a step. It was called the finger dance because it usually ended when one of the dancers lost one… or two, or five.</p>
      <p>Neither the dancers nor the drinkers took much note of Theon Greyjoy as he strode to the dais. Lord Balon occupied the Seastone Chair, carved in the shape of a great kraken from an immense block of oily black stone. Legend said that the First Men had found it standing on the shore of Old Wyk when they came to the Iron Islands. To the left of the high seat were Theon’s uncles. Asha was ensconced at his right hand, in the place of honor. “You come late, Theon,” Lord Balon observed.</p>
      <p>“I ask your pardon.” Theon took the empty seat beside Asha. Leaning close, he hissed in her ear, “You’re in my place.”</p>
      <p>She turned to him with innocent eyes. “Brother, surely you are mistaken. Your place is at Winterfell.” Her smile cut. “And where are all your pretty clothes? I heard you fancied silk and velvet against your skin.” She was in soft green wool herself, simply cut, the fabric clinging to the slender lines of her body.</p>
      <p>“Your hauberk must have rusted away, sister,” he threw back. “A great pity. I’d like to see you all in iron.”</p>
      <p>Asha only laughed. “You may yet, little brother… if you think your <emphasis>Sea Bitch</emphasis> can keep up with my <emphasis>Black Wind.</emphasis>” One of their father’s thralls came near, bearing a flagon of wine. “Are you drinking ale or wine tonight, Theon?” She leaned over close. “Or is it still a taste of my mother’s milk you thirst for?”</p>
      <p>He flushed. “Wine,” he told the thrall. Asha turned away and banged on the table, shouting for ale.</p>
      <p>Theon hacked a loaf of bread in half, hollowed out a trencher, and summoned a cook to fill it with fish stew. The smell of the thick cream made him a little ill, but he forced himself to eat some. He’d drunk enough wine to float him through two meals. <emphasis>If I retch, it will be on her.</emphasis> “Does Father know that you’ve married his shipwright?” he asked his sister.</p>
      <p>“No more than Sigrin does.” She gave a shrug. “<emphasis>Esgred</emphasis> was the first ship he built. He named her after his mother. I would be hard-pressed to say which he loves best.”</p>
      <p>“Every word you spoke to me was a lie.”</p>
      <p>“Not <emphasis>every</emphasis> word. Remember when I told you I like to be on top?” Asha grinned.</p>
      <p>That only made him angrier. “All that about being a woman wed, and new with child…”</p>
      <p>“Oh, that part was true enough.” Asha leapt to her feet. <emphasis>“Rolfe, here,”</emphasis> she shouted down at one of the finger dancers, holding up a hand. He saw her, spun, and suddenly an axe came flying from his hand, the blade gleaming as it tumbled end over end through the torchlight. Theon had time for a choked gasp before Asha snatched the axe from the air and slammed it down into the table, splitting his trencher in two and splattering his mantle with drippings. “There’s my lord husband.” His sister reached down inside her gown and drew a dirk from between her breasts. “And here’s my sweet suckling babe.”</p>
      <p>He could not imagine how he looked at that moment, but suddenly Theon Greyjoy realized that the Great Hall was ringing with laughter, all of it at him. Even his father was smiling, gods be damned, and his uncle Victarion chuckled aloud. The best response he could summon was a queasy grin. <emphasis>We shall see who is laughing when all this is done, bitch.</emphasis></p>
      <p>Asha wrenched the axe out of the table and flung it back down at the dancers, to whistles and loud cheers. “You’d do well to heed what I told you about choosing a crew.” A thrall offered them a platter, and she stabbed a salted fish and ate it off the end of her dirk. “If you had troubled to learn the first thing of Sigrin, I could never have fooled you. Ten years a wolf, and you land here and think to prince about the islands, but you know nothing and no one. Why should men fight and die for you?”</p>
      <p>“I am their lawful prince,” Theon said stiffly.</p>
      <p>“By the laws of the green lands, you might be. But we make our own laws here, or have you forgotten?”</p>
      <p>Scowling, Theon turned to contemplate the leaking trencher before him. He would have stew in his lap before long. He shouted for a thrall to clean it up. <emphasis>Half my life I have waited to come home, and for what? Mockery and disregard?</emphasis> This was not the Pyke he remembered. Or <emphasis>did</emphasis> he remember? He had been so young when they took him away to hold hostage.</p>
      <p>The feast was a meager enough thing, a succession of fish stews, black bread, and spiceless goat. The tastiest thing Theon found to eat was an onion pie. Ale and wine continued to flow well after the last of the courses had been cleared away.</p>
      <p>Lord Balon Greyjoy rose from the Seastone Chair. “Have done with your drink and come to my solar,” he commanded his companions on the dais. “We have plans to lay.” He left them with no other word, flanked by two of his guards. His brothers followed in short order. Theon rose to go after them.</p>
      <p>“My little brother is in a rush to be off.” Asha raised her drinking horn and beckoned for more ale.</p>
      <p>“Our lord father is waiting.”</p>
      <p>“And has, for many a year. It will do him no harm to wait a little longer… but if you fear his wrath, scurry after him by all means. You ought to have no trouble catching our uncles.” She smiled. “One is drunk on seawater, after all, and the other is a great grey bullock so dim he’ll probably get lost.”</p>
      <p>Theon sat back down, annoyed. “I run after no man.”</p>
      <p>“No man, but every woman?”</p>
      <p>“It was not me who grabbed your cock.”</p>
      <p>“I don’t have one, remember? You grabbed every other bit of me quick enough.”</p>
      <p>He could feel the flush creeping up his cheeks. “I’m a man with a man’s hungers. What sort of unnatural creature are you?”</p>
      <p>“Only a shy maid.” Asha’s hand darted out under the table to give his cock a squeeze. Theon nearly jumped from his chair. “What, don’t you want me to steer you into port, brother?”</p>
      <p>“Marriage is not for you,” Theon decided. “When I rule, I believe I will pack you off to the silent sisters.” He lurched to his feet and strode off unsteadily to find his father.</p>
      <p>Rain was falling by the time he reached the swaying bridge out to the Sea Tower. His stomach was crashing and churning like the waves below, and wine had unsteadied his feet. Theon gritted his teeth and gripped the rope tightly as he made his way across, pretending that it was Asha’s neck he was clutching.</p>
      <p>The solar was as damp and drafty as ever. Buried under his sealskin robes, his father sat before the brazier with his brothers on either side of him. Victarion was talking of tides and winds when Theon entered, but Lord Balon waved him silent. “I have made my plans. It is time you heard them.”</p>
      <p>“I have some suggestions—”</p>
      <p>“When I require your counsel I shall ask for it,” his father said. “We have had a bird from Old Wyk. Dagmer is bringing the Drumms and Stonehouses. If the god grants us good winds, we will sail when they arrive… or <emphasis>you</emphasis> will. I mean for you to strike the first blow, Theon. You shall take eight longships north—”</p>
      <p><emphasis>“Eight?”</emphasis> His face reddened. “What can I hope to accomplish with only eight longships?”</p>
      <p>“You are to harry the Stony Shore, raiding the fishing villages and sinking any ships you chance to meet. It may be that you will draw some of the northern lords out from behind their stone walls. Aeron will accompany you, and Dagmer Cleftjaw.”</p>
      <p>“May the Drowned God bless our swords,” the priest said.</p>
      <p>Theon felt as if he’d been slapped. He was being sent to do reaver’s work, burning fishermen out of their hovels and raping their ugly daughters, and yet it seemed Lord Balon did not trust him sufficiently to do even that much. Bad enough to have to suffer the Damphair’s scowls and chidings. With Dagmer Cleftjaw along as well, his command would be purely nominal.</p>
      <p>“Asha my daughter,” Lord Balon went on, and Theon turned to see that his sister had slipped in silently, “you shall take thirty longships of picked men round Sea Dragon Point. Land upon the tidal flats north of Deepwood Motte. March quickly, and the castle may fall before they even know you are upon them.”</p>
      <p>Asha smiled like a cat in cream. “I’ve always wanted a castle,” she said sweetly.</p>
      <p>“Then take one.”</p>
      <p>Theon had to bite his tongue. Deepwood Motte was the stronghold of the Glovers. With both Robett and Galbart warring in the south, it would be lightly held, and once the castle fell the ironmen would have a secure base in the heart of the north. <emphasis>I should be the one sent to take Deepwood.</emphasis> He <emphasis>knew</emphasis> Deepwood Motte, he had visited the Glovers several times with Eddard Stark.</p>
      <p>“Victarion,” Lord Balon said to his brother, “the main thrust shall fall to you. When my sons have struck their blows, Winterfell must respond. You should meet small opposition as you sail up Saltspear and the Fever River. At the headwaters, you will be less than twenty miles from Moat Cailin. The Neck is the key to the kingdom. Already we command the western seas. Once we hold Moat Cailin, the pup will not be able to win back to the north… and if he is fool enough to try, his enemies will seal the south end of the causeway behind him, and Robb the boy will find himself caught like a rat in a bottle.”</p>
      <p>Theon could keep silent no longer. “A bold plan, Father, but the lords in their castles—”</p>
      <p>Lord Balon rode over him. “The lords are gone south with the pup. Those who remained behind are the cravens, old men, and green boys. They will yield or fall, one by one. Winterfell may defy us for a year, but what of it? The rest shall be ours, forest and field and hall, and we shall make the folk our thralls and salt wives.”</p>
      <p>Aeron Damphair raised his arms. “And the waters of wrath will rise high, and the Drowned God will spread his dominion across the green lands!”</p>
      <p>“What is dead can never die,” Victarion intoned. Lord Balon and Asha echoed his words, and Theon had no choice but to mumble along with them. And then it was done.</p>
      <p>Outside the rain was falling harder than ever. The rope bridge twisted and writhed under his feet. Theon Greyjoy stopped in the center of the span and contemplated the rocks below. The sound of the waves was a crashing roar, and he could taste the salt spray on his lips. A sudden gust of wind made him lose his footing, and he stumbled to his knees.</p>
      <p>Asha helped him rise. “You can’t hold your wine either, brother.”</p>
      <p>Theon leaned on her shoulder and let her guide him across the rain-slick boards. “I liked you better when you were Esgred,” he told her accusingly.</p>
      <p>She laughed. “That’s fair. I liked <emphasis>you</emphasis> better when you were nine.”</p>
    </section>
    <section>
      <title>
        <p>TYRION</p>
      </title>
      <p>Through the door came the soft sound of the high harp, mingled with a trilling of pipes. The singer’s voice was muffled by the thick walls, yet Tyrion knew the verse. <emphasis>I loved a maid as fair as summer,</emphasis> he remembered, <emphasis>with sunlight in her hair…</emphasis></p>
      <p>Ser Meryn Trant guarded the queen’s door this night. His muttered “My lord” struck Tyrion as a tad grudging, but he opened the door nonetheless. The song broke off abruptly as he strode into his sister’s bedchamber.</p>
      <p>Cersei was reclining on a pile of cushions. Her feet were bare, her golden hair artfully tousled, her robe a green-and-gold samite that caught the light of the candles and shimmered as she looked up. “Sweet sister,” Tyrion said, “how beautiful you look tonight.” He turned to the singer. “And you as well, cousin. I had no notion you had such a lovely voice.”</p>
      <p>The compliment made Ser Lancel sulky; perhaps he thought he was being mocked. It seemed to Tyrion that the lad had grown three inches since being knighted. Lancel had thick sandy hair, green Lannister eyes, and a line of soft blond fuzz on his upper lip. At sixteen, he was cursed with all the certainty of youth, unleavened by any trace of humor or self-doubt, and wed to the arrogance that came so naturally to those born blond and strong and handsome. His recent elevation had only made him worse. “Did Her Grace send for you?” the boy demanded.</p>
      <p>“Not that I recall,” Tyrion admitted. “It grieves me to disturb your revels, Lancel, but as it happens, I have matters of import to discuss with my sister.”</p>
      <p>Cersei regarded him suspiciously. “If you are here about those begging brothers, Tyrion, spare me your reproaches. I won’t have them spreading their filthy treasons in the streets. They can preach to each other in the dungeons.”</p>
      <p>“And count themselves lucky that they have such a gentle queen,” added Lancel. “I would have had their tongues out.”</p>
      <p>“One even dared to say that the gods were punishing us because Jaime murdered the rightful king,” Cersei declared. “It will not be borne, Tyrion. I gave you ample opportunity to deal with these lice, but you and your Ser Jacelyn did nothing, so I commanded Vylarr to attend to the matter.”</p>
      <p>“And so he did.” Tyrion <emphasis>had</emphasis> been annoyed when the red cloaks had dragged a half dozen of the scabrous prophets down to the dungeons without consulting him, but they were not important enough to battle over. “No doubt we will all be better off for a little quiet in the streets. That is not why I came. I have tidings I know you will be anxious to hear, sweet sister, but they are best spoken of privily.”</p>
      <p>“Very well.” The harpist and the piper bowed and hurried out, while Cersei kissed her cousin chastely on the cheek. “Leave us, Lancel. My brother’s harmless when he’s alone. If he’d brought his pets, we’d smell them.”</p>
      <p>The young knight gave his cousin a baleful glance and pulled the door shut forcefully behind him. “I’ll have you know I make Shagga bathe once a fortnight,” Tyrion said when he was gone.</p>
      <p>“You’re very pleased with yourself, aren’t you? Why?”</p>
      <p>“Why not?” Tyrion said. Every day, every night, hammers rang along the Street of Steel, and the great chain grew longer. He hopped up onto the great canopied bed. “Is this the bed where Robert died? I’m surprised you kept it.”</p>
      <p>“It gives me sweet dreams,” she said. “Now spit out your business and waddle away, Imp.”</p>
      <p>Tyrion smiled. “Lord Stannis has sailed from Dragonstone.”</p>
      <p>Cersei bolted to her feet. “And yet you sit there grinning like a harvest-day pumpkin? Has Bywater called out the City Watch? We must send a bird to Harrenhal at once.” He was laughing by then. She seized him by the shoulders and shook him. “Stop it. Are you mad, or drunk? <emphasis>Stop it!</emphasis>”</p>
      <p>It was all he could do to get out the words. “I can’t,” he gasped. “It’s too… gods, too funny… Stannis…”</p>
      <p>
        <emphasis>“What?”</emphasis>
      </p>
      <p>“He hasn’t sailed against us,” Tyrion managed. “He’s laid siege to Storm’s End. Renly is riding to meet him.”</p>
      <p>His sister’s nails dug painfully into his arms. For a moment she stared incredulous, as if he had begun to gibber in an unknown tongue. “Stannis and Renly are fighting <emphasis>each other?</emphasis>” When he nodded, Cersei began to chuckle. “Gods be good,” she gasped, “I’m starting to believe that Robert was the <emphasis>clever</emphasis> one.”</p>
      <p>Tyrion threw back his head and roared. They laughed together. Cersei pulled him off the bed and whirled him around and even hugged him, for a moment as giddy as a girl. By the time she let go of him, Tyrion was breathless and dizzy. He staggered to her sideboard and put out a hand to steady himself.</p>
      <p>“Do you think it will truly come to battle between them? If they should come to some accord—”</p>
      <p>“They won’t,” Tyrion said. “They are too different and yet too much alike, and neither could ever stomach the other.”</p>
      <p>“And Stannis has always felt he was cheated of Storm’s End,” Cersei said thoughtfully. “The ancestral seat of House Baratheon, his by rights… if you knew how many times he came to Robert singing that same dull song in that gloomy aggrieved tone he has. When Robert gave the place to Renly, Stannis clenched his jaw so tight I thought his teeth would shatter.”</p>
      <p>“He took it as a slight.”</p>
      <p>“It was meant as a slight,” Cersei said.</p>
      <p>“Shall we raise a cup to brotherly love?”</p>
      <p>“Yes,” she answered, breathless. “Oh, gods, yes.”</p>
      <p>His back was to her as he filled two cups with sweet Arbor red. It was the easiest thing in the world to sprinkle a pinch of fine powder into hers. “To Stannis!” he said as he handed her the wine. <emphasis>Harmless when I’m alone, am I?</emphasis></p>
      <p>“To Renly!” she replied, laughing. “May they battle long and hard, and the Others take them both!”</p>
      <p><emphasis>Is this the Cersei that Jaime sees?</emphasis> When she smiled, you saw how beautiful she was, truly. <emphasis>I loved a maid as fair as summer, with sunlight in her hair.</emphasis> He almost felt sorry for poisoning her.</p>
      <p>It was the next morning as he broke his fast that her messenger arrived. The queen was indisposed and would not be able to leave her chambers. <emphasis>Not able to leave her privy, more like.</emphasis> Tyrion made the proper sympathetic noises and sent word to Cersei to rest easy, he would treat with Ser Cleos as they’d planned.</p>
      <p>The Iron Throne of Aegon the Conqueror was a tangle of nasty barbs and jagged metal teeth waiting for any fool who tried to sit too comfortably, and the steps made his stunted legs cramp as he climbed up to it, all too aware of what an absurd spectacle he must be. Yet there was one thing to be said for it. It was <emphasis>high.</emphasis></p>
      <p>Lannister guardsmen stood silent in their crimson cloaks and lion-crested halfhelms. Ser Jacelyn’s gold cloaks faced them across the hall. The steps to the throne were flanked by Bronn and Ser Preston of the Kingsguard. Courtiers filled the gallery while supplicants clustered near the towering oak-and-bronze doors. Sansa Stark looked especially lovely this morning, though her face was as pale as milk. Lord Gyles stood coughing, while poor cousin Tyrek wore his bridegroom’s mantle of miniver and velvet. Since his marriage to little Lady Ermesande three days past, the other squires had taken to calling him “Wet Nurse” and asking him what sort of swaddling clothes his bride wore on their wedding night.</p>
      <p>Tyrion looked down on them all, and found he liked it. “Call forth Ser Cleos Frey.” His voice rang off the stone walls and down the length of the hall. He liked that too. <emphasis>A pity Shae could not be here to see this,</emphasis> he reflected. She’d asked to come, but it was impossible.</p>
      <p>Ser Cleos made the long walk between the gold cloaks and the crimson, looking neither right nor left. As he knelt, Tyrion observed that his cousin was losing his hair.</p>
      <p>“Ser Cleos,” Littlefinger said from the council table, “you have our thanks for bringing us this peace offer from Lord Stark.”</p>
      <p>Grand Maester Pycelle cleared his throat. “The Queen Regent, the King’s Hand, and the small council have considered the terms offered by this self-styled King in the North. Sad to say, they will not do, and you must tell these northmen so, ser.”</p>
      <p>“Here are <emphasis>our</emphasis> terms,” said Tyrion. “Robb Stark must lay down his sword, swear fealty, and return to Winterfell. He must free my brother unharmed, and place his host under Jaime’s command, to march against the rebels Renly and Stannis Baratheon. Each of Stark’s bannermen must send us a son as hostage. A daughter will suffice where there is no son. They shall be treated gently and given high places here at court, so long as their fathers commit no new treasons.”</p>
      <p>Cleos Frey looked ill. “My lord Hand,” he said, “Lord Stark will never consent to these terms.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>We never expected he would, Cleos.</emphasis> “Tell him that we have raised another great host at Casterly Rock, that soon it will march on him from the west while my lord father advances from the east. Tell him that he stands alone, without hope of allies. Stannis and Renly Baratheon war against each other, and the Prince of Dorne has consented to wed his son Trystane to the Princess Myrcella.” Murmurs of delight and consternation alike arose from the gallery and the back of the hall.</p>
      <p>“As to this of my cousins,” Tyrion went on, “we offer Harrion Karstark and Ser Wylis Manderly for Willem Lannister, and Lord Cerwyn and Ser Donnel Locke for your brother Tion. Tell Stark that two Lannisters are worth four northmen in any season.” He waited for the laughter to die. “His father’s bones he shall have, as a gesture of Joffrey’s good faith.”</p>
      <p>“Lord Stark asked for his sisters and his father’s sword as well,” Ser Cleos reminded him.</p>
      <p>Ser Ilyn Payne stood mute, the hilt of Eddard Stark’s greatsword rising over one shoulder. “Ice,” said Tyrion. “He’ll have that when he makes his peace with us, not before.”</p>
      <p>“As you say. And his sisters?”</p>
      <p>Tyrion glanced toward Sansa, and felt a stab of pity as he said, “Until such time as he frees my brother Jaime, unharmed, they shall remain here as hostages. How well they are treated depends on him.” <emphasis>And if the gods are good, Bywater will find Arya alive, before Robb learns she’s gone missing.</emphasis></p>
      <p>“I shall bring him your message, my lord.”</p>
      <p>Tyrion plucked at one of the twisted blades that sprang from the arm of the throne. <emphasis>And now the thrust.</emphasis> “Vylarr,” he called.</p>
      <p>“My lord.”</p>
      <p>“The men Stark sent are sufficient to protect Lord Eddard’s bones, but a Lannister should have a Lannister escort,” Tyrion declared. “Ser Cleos is the queen’s cousin, and mine. We shall sleep more easily if you would see him safely back to Riverrun.”</p>
      <p>“As you command. How many men should I take?”</p>
      <p>“Why, all of them.”</p>
      <p>Vylarr stood like a man made of stone. It was Grand Maester Pycelle who rose, gasping, “My lord Hand, that cannot… your father, Lord Tywin himself, he sent these good men to our city to protect Queen Cersei and her children…”</p>
      <p>“The Kingsguard and the City Watch protect them well enough. The gods speed you on your way, Vylarr.”</p>
      <p>At the council table Varys smiled knowingly, Littlefinger sat feigning boredom, and Pycelle gaped like a fish, pale and confused. A herald stepped forward. “If any man has other matters to set before the King’s Hand, let him speak now or go forth and hold his silence.”</p>
      <p>“<emphasis>I</emphasis> will be heard.” A slender man all in black pushed his way between the Redwyne twins.</p>
      <p>“Ser <emphasis>Alliser!</emphasis>” Tyrion exclaimed. “Why, I had no notion that you’d come to court. You should have sent me word.”</p>
      <p>“I have, as well you know.” Thorne was as prickly as his name, a spare, sharp-featured man of fifty, hard-eyed and hard-handed, his black hair streaked with grey. “I have been shunned, ignored, and left to wait like some baseborn servant.”</p>
      <p>“Truly? Bronn, this was not well done. Ser Alliser and I are old friends. We walked the Wall together.”</p>
      <p>“Sweet Ser Alliser,” murmured Varys, “you must not think too harshly of us. So many seek our Joffrey’s grace, in these troubled and tumultuous times.”</p>
      <p>“More troubled than you know, eunuch.”</p>
      <p>“To his face we call him <emphasis>Lord</emphasis> Eunuch,” quipped Littlefinger.</p>
      <p>“How may we be of help to you, good brother?” Grand Maester Pycelle asked in soothing tones.</p>
      <p>“The Lord Commander sent me to His Grace the king,” Thorne answered. “The matter is too grave to be left to servants.”</p>
      <p>“The king is playing with his new crossbow,” Tyrion said. Ridding himself of Joffrey had required only an ungainly Myrish crossbow that threw three quarrels at a time, and nothing would do but that he try it at once. “You can speak to servants or hold your silence.”</p>
      <p>“As you will,” Ser Alliser said, displeasure in every word. “I am sent to tell you that we found two rangers, long missing. They were dead, yet when we brought the corpses back to the Wall they rose again in the night. One slew Ser Jaremy Rykker, while the second tried to murder the Lord Commander.”</p>
      <p>Distantly, Tyrion heard someone snigger. <emphasis>Does he mean to mock me with this folly?</emphasis> He shifted uneasily and glanced down at Varys, Littlefinger, and Pycelle, wondering if one of them had a role in this. A dwarf enjoyed at best a tenuous hold on dignity. Once the court and kingdom started to laugh at him, he was doomed. And yet… and yet…</p>
      <p>Tyrion remembered a cold night under the stars when he’d stood beside the boy Jon Snow and a great white wolf atop the Wall at the end of the world, gazing out at the trackless dark beyond. He had felt — what?<emphasis> — something,</emphasis> to be sure, a dread that had cut like that frigid northern wind. A wolf had howled off in the night, and the sound had sent a shiver through him.</p>
      <p><emphasis>Don’t be a fool,</emphasis> he told himself. <emphasis>A wolf, a wind, a dark forest, it meant nothing. And yet… </emphasis>He had come to have a liking for old Jeor Mormont during his time at Castle Black. “I trust that the Old Bear survived this attack?”</p>
      <p>“He did.”</p>
      <p>“And that your brothers killed these, ah, dead men?”</p>
      <p>“We did.”</p>
      <p>“You’re certain that they are dead this time?” Tyrion asked mildly. When Bronn choked on a snort of laughter, he knew how he must proceed. “Truly truly dead?”</p>
      <p>“They were dead the first time,” Ser Alliser snapped. “Pale and cold, with black hands and feet. I brought Jared’s hand, torn from his corpse by the bastard’s wolf.”</p>
      <p>Littlefinger stirred. “And where is this charming token?”</p>
      <p>Ser Alliser frowned uncomfortably. “It… rotted to pieces while I waited, unheard. There’s naught left to show but bones.”</p>
      <p>Titters echoed through the hall. “Lord Baelish,” Tyrion called down to Littlefinger, “buy our brave Ser Alliser a hundred spades to take back to the Wall with him.”</p>
      <p>“Spades?” Ser Alliser narrowed his eyes suspiciously.</p>
      <p>“If you <emphasis>bury</emphasis> your dead, they won’t come walking,” Tyrion told him, and the court laughed openly. “Spades will end your troubles, with some strong backs to wield them. Ser Jacelyn, see that the good brother has his pick of the city dungeons.”</p>
      <p>Ser Jacelyn Bywater said, “As you will, my lord, but the cells are near empty. Yoren took all the likely men.”</p>
      <p>“Arrest some more, then,” Tyrion told him. “Or spread the word that there’s bread and turnips on the Wall, and they’ll go of their own accord.” The city had too many mouths to feed, and the Night’s Watch a perpetual need of men. At Tyrion’s signal, the herald cried an end, and the hall began to empty.</p>
      <p>Ser Alliser Thorne was not so easily dismissed. He was waiting at the foot of the Iron Throne when Tyrion descended. “Do you think I sailed all the way from Eastwatch-by-the-Sea to be mocked by the likes of you?” he fumed, blocking the way. “This is no jape. I saw it with my own eyes. I tell you, the dead walk.”</p>
      <p>“You should try to kill them more thoroughly.” Tyrion pushed past. Ser Alliser made to grab his sleeve, but Preston Greenfield thrust him back. “No closer, ser.”</p>
      <p>Thorne knew better than to challenge a knight of the Kingsguard. “You are a fool, Imp,” he shouted at Tyrion’s back.</p>
      <p>The dwarf turned to face him. “Me? Truly? Then why were they laughing at you, I wonder?” He smiled wanly. “You came for men, did you not?”</p>
      <p>“The cold winds are rising. The Wall must be held.”</p>
      <p>“And to hold it you need men, which I’ve given you… as you might have noted, if your ears heard anything but insults. Take them, thank me, and begone before I’m forced to take a crab fork to you again. Give my warm regards to Lord Mormont… and to Jon Snow as well.” Bronn seized Ser Alliser by the elbow and marched him forcefully from the hall.</p>
      <p>Grand Maester Pycelle had already scuttled off, but Varys and Littlefinger had watched it all, start to finish. “I grow ever more admiring of you, my lord,” confessed the eunuch. “You appease the Stark boy with his father’s bones and strip your sister of her protectors in one swift stroke. You give that black brother the men he seeks, rid the city of some hungry mouths, yet make it all seem mockery so none may say that the dwarf fears snarks and grumkins. Oh, deftly done.”</p>
      <p>Littlefinger stroked his beard. “Do you truly mean to send away all your guards, Lannister?”</p>
      <p>“No, I mean to send away all my <emphasis>sister’s</emphasis> guards.”</p>
      <p>“The queen will never allow that.”</p>
      <p>“Oh, I think she may. I <emphasis>am</emphasis> her brother, and when you’ve known me longer, you’ll learn that I mean everything I say.”</p>
      <p>“Even the lies?”</p>
      <p>“<emphasis>Especially</emphasis> the lies. Lord Petyr, I sense that you are unhappy with me.”</p>
      <p>“I love you as much as I ever have, my lord. Though I do not relish being played for a fool. If Myrcella weds Trystane Martell, she can scarcely wed Robert Arryn, can she?”</p>
      <p>“Not without causing a great scandal,” he admitted. “I regret my little ruse, Lord Petyr, but when we spoke, I could not know the Dornishmen would accept my offer.”</p>
      <p>Littlefinger was not appeased. “I do not like being lied to, my lord. Leave me out of your next deception.”</p>
      <p><emphasis>Only if you’ll do the same for me,</emphasis> Tyrion thought, glancing at the dagger sheathed at Littlefinger’s hip. “If I have given offense, I am deeply sorry. All men know how much we love you, my lord. And how much we need you.”</p>
      <p>“Try and remember that.” With that Littlefinger left them.</p>
      <p>“Walk with me, Varys,” said Tyrion. They left through the king’s door behind the throne, the eunuch’s slippers whisking lightly over the stone.</p>
      <p>“Lord Baelish has the truth of it, you know. The queen will never permit you to send away her guard.”</p>
      <p>“She will. You’ll see to that.”</p>
      <p>A smile flickered across Varys’s plump lips. “Will I?”</p>
      <p>“Oh, for a certainty. You’ll tell her it is part of my scheme to free Jaime.”</p>
      <p>Varys stroked a powdered cheek. “This would doubtless involve the four men your man Bronn searched for so diligently in all the low places of King’s Landing. A thief, a poisoner, a mummer, and a murderer.”</p>
      <p>“Put them in crimson cloaks and lion helms, they’ll look no different from any other guardsmen. I searched for some time for a ruse that might get them into Riverrun before I thought to hide them in plain sight. They’ll ride in by the main gate, flying Lannister banners and escorting Lord Eddard’s bones.” He smiled crookedly. “Four men alone would be watched vigilantly. Four among a hundred can lose themselves. So I must send the true guardsmen as well as the false… as you’ll tell my sister.”</p>
      <p>“And for the sake of her beloved brother, she will consent, despite her misgivings.” They made their way down a deserted colonnade. “Still, the loss of her red cloaks will surely make her uneasy.”</p>
      <p>“I like her uneasy,” said Tyrion.</p>
      <p>Ser Cleos Frey left that very afternoon, escorted by Vylarr and a hundred red-cloaked Lannister guardsmen. The men Robb Stark had sent joined them at the King’s Gate for the long ride west.</p>
      <p>Tyrion found Timett dicing with his Burned Men in the barracks. “Come to my solar at midnight.” Timett gave him a hard one-eyed stare, a curt nod. He was not one for long speeches.</p>
